Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: Conference & Workshop Support: Science for the People, April 2014 at UMass Amherst.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Overview

This award is to support a three-day conference on the history of the organization Science for the People (SftP), which was active during the 1970s and 1980s, and its relevance for the interface of science and society today. The conference will bring together veteran members of the organization and other scientists, STS scholars, and students. The conference will include keynote speakers offering SftP and STS perspectives, and panels on the historical and contemporary significance of SftP to issues that the organization addressed in the past and continue to face society today.

Intellectual Merit

The conference will contribute to three areas of growing importance within STS. First, it will support the effort to replace the simplistic understanding of "science communication" promoted by mainstream "public understanding of science" circles with a more sophisticated analysis that accounts for political, economic, and social power structures. Second, it will provide additional resources for the study of science and political engagement. Third, it will offer a venue for the further exploration of what some STS scholars have termed "activist-oriented STS," an area that has witnessed a number of rigorous and influential contributions recently. A major lasting contribution will be the compilation of written historical narratives by former members of SftP with analysis by STS graduate students.

Broader Impacts

The conference will benefit scientists and students. Scientists will gain exposure to SftP history and STS perspectives, and so they will acquire a better understanding of the social, political, economic, and cultural contexts of the problems they seek to address through their scientific work. Students will encounter in SftP participants successful examples of people who have put their science education to work in ways consistent with their social and political goals. The conference website is already serving to bring members of these groups into productive conversation. After the conference, the website will provide the public with accessible scholarly analysis of the history of SftP, historical materials produced by SftP in text-searchable pdf format, a summary of the conference?s major themes, panel descriptions, and video recordings of the panels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
"Science for the People: The 1970s and Today"

A 3-Day Conference (11-13 April 2014) at UMass Amherst

Hosted by the UMass Social Thought & Political Economy Program

Conference video and further resources at http://science-for-the-people.org

 

The U.S.-based organization Science for the People (SftP) arose in 1969 out of the anti-war movement and lasted until 1989. With a Marxist analysis and non-hierarchical governing structure, SftP tackled the militarization of scientific research, the corporate control of research agendas, the political implications of sociobiology and other scientific theories, the environmental consequences of energy policy, inequalities in health care, and many other issues. Its members opposed racism, sexism, and classism in science and above all sought to mobilize people working in scientific fields to become active in agitating for science, technology, and medicine that would serve social needs rather than military and corporate interests. They organized in universities and communities, published a magazine offering sharp political analysis, and sought meaningful scientific exchange internationally in Vietnam, China, Cuba, Nicaragua, and other countries.

 

This conference on the history and legacy of Science for the People provided a forum for about 200 people—including veteran members of SftP along with other scientists, scholars, activists, and students—to come together in lively dialogue. More than 30 organizations belonging to UMass, local colleges, and the wider community signed on as co-sponsors, and more than 60 people presented at the conference in 16 speaker and panel events. Together, we reconstructed the analysis Science for the People brought to bear on the political, economic, and social power structures that shape scientific research and debated its strengths, weaknesses, and current relevance. Issue-themed panels further provided opportunities to discuss the implications of this history for current movements around climate change, the militarization of science, agricultural science and food justice, the scientific construction of race and gender, and many other topics. Highlights included a panel of former SftP members relating "Stories from the Movement," a panel of Science and Technology Studies (STS) scholars on the historical and sociological significance of SftP, a keynote lecture by former SftP member and University of Michigan ecologist John Vandermeer, and a presentation on Science and Ideology by former SftP member and noted Marxist biologist Richard Levins.

 

The website http://science-for-the-people.org will be maintained as a hub for studying the history and legacy of Science for the People. It includes video of all conference sessions, along with abstracts and presentation files for many of the presentations, and a wide assortment of historical materials on SftP, including many of SftP's own publications along with FBI files obtained through a FOIA request.

 

In addition, five graduate students are collaborating with the project's PI to create an edited volume of primary sources introducing SftP's analysis of science and society to a broad audience.
